ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: This was a synchronous performance studio, with one virtual/synchronous training session per week with the Teaching Fellow.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed my artistic voice, confidence, physical ease in performance and uncovered new ways of interpreting classic work.
I learned about how to approach the text of Shakespeare. I gained insight into my own habits and tools to address those habits and learn new skills.

A totally transformative concept of acting as a vehicle for affecting the characters, audience, and space around you. An outward, more physical and audial approach to acting rather than an inward, cerebral one.

(Some) fundamentals of acting Shakespeare. We start with the basics of meter, scansion, and paraphrasing. By the end, we focus on techniques like alacrity, selectivity, etcfeedback is personalized to address your own weaknesses. I learned how to be a much more convincing actor by the end.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course is rigorous, exciting and a profound place for self-reflection and growth. I felt I was afforded an incredible amount of personal attention, and loved the one-on-one workshopping we were able to do.
Strengths: James Bundy's teaching, Shakespeare's work

There are many strengths to the course. Small class size ensures personalized feedback. There is an excellent support system with weekly tutorials and workshops. And most importantly, you get access to Bundy's brilliance. There are few weaknessesthe only one I can think of is perhaps making a workshop schedule before or at the beginning of class. That might resolve some of the anxiety/awkwardness of either rushing to be next or waiting and hoping someone else volunteers.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was really helpful to take a break at the midpoint in the class, since it was a four-hour course on screen.
I felt that the four hour block was difficult over zoom. Perhaps two two hour blocks would be better to sustain attention and prevent screen fatigue.

Excellent adjustment to Zoom. We were lucky and never ran into connection issues (as far as I can remember). It obviously would be a problem if you're audio/video cut out or became choppy, but that was rarely an issue, and when it was Bundy handled it with grace.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you have the opportunity to take this course, you absolutely should! It has fundamentally changed me as a performer, and I am so grateful for the feedback I received from beginning to end.
Yes. It's a great opportunity to work with Professor Bundy. It's also a great opportunity to take a course different from the rest of your schedule.

If youre remotely interested in acting and want to learn how to do it better, you MUST take this course with James Bundy. Hes a MASTER teacher. Working with him is eye opening and transformative. Even virtually, this ended up being a tie for my favorite Yale course.

Yes! Certainly take this courseeven without acting experience, it is tremendous. If you have the opportunity, I highly recommend you take it! Only point: if you do not need the course and are taking it for fun/personal enrichment, consider taking it credit/d/fail. You likely won't get a bad grade, but it's not the automatic A that some other classes are.
